Do Premier League managers have a chance?

Luke Gardener discusses the sacking of ex-Newcastle manager Chris Hughton and explores its meaning in the wider context of the game. (Thumbnail credit The recently departed Chris Hughton, unfairly dismissed by Newcastle owner Mike Ashley. Image: blenky64 via Flickr Creative Commons)

Nouse Sport Podcast

By James Bithell

The week nine edition of the Nouse Sport Podcast returns in an attempt to provide both laughs and sporting analysis. Have a listen (Thumbnail credit Newcastle's Goal Shooter, in the background of this picture, is compared to Niall Quinn in this week's Nouse Sport Podcast. Image: Peter Iveson)

Men's badminton firsts hammered by league leaders

The men's badminton firsts fell to a disappointing 7-1 loss to league leaders Leeds Metropolitan Carnegie on another snowy Wednesday yesterday (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

Netball seconds thwarted by Newcastle

With BUCS Wednesday once again hit hard by the weather, the netball seconds were defeated 46-28 by Newcastle University thirds in a cup match (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Asfahani announces big changes to both Roses and Varsity

York Sport President Sam Asfahani has announced big changes to both Roses and Varsity (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

Nouse Sport Podcast

By James Bithell

The perfect distraction to that boring essay is here, the week 8 edition of the Nouse Sport Podcast. Get involved. (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Badminton seconds defeated by York St John

BUCS fixtures were massively disrupted by the snow today with only one game going ahead, the men's badminton seconds against local rivals York St John firsts. St John came out on top, winning 5-3 (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Victory for Water Polo in first game of season

York men's water polo side got their BUCS season off to a winning start as they overcame Bolton University 6-2 (Thumbnail credit Image: Elliot Thurland)

Another win for women's rugby

The women's rugby team continued their impressive campaign with a 33-0 win over Bradford University last Wednesday (Thumbnail credit Image: Courtesy of York Women's Rugby Club)

Braid Hills Race: Bonnie Scotland proves a sheer success for UYAC.

The Athletics and Running Club travelled to Edinburgh a few weeks ago to take part in the annual Braids Hill Race in what was a successful day for the club (Thumbnail credit Image: Jess Haines)

Netballers lose out to Sheffield Hallam seconds

York's netballers' cup run came to and end on Wednesday as they lost out 45-33 to Sheffield Hallam seconds. (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

Badminton men held to 4-4 draw

A relegation scrap between York and Sheffield saw neither side come out on top as they shared the spoils in a 4-4 draw (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Cup success for York men's squash team

The men's squash team overcame their recent issues to progress in the cup, beating Leeds seconds 3-0 (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Men's volleyball taste victory again

The men's volleyball team continued their upsurge in fortunes as they overcame Sheffield Hallam seconds 3 - 0 (25-21, 25-23, 25-18) (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Women's fencers narrowly fail to beat reigning champions Edinburgh

York women's fencing team took on reigning Northern Premier League champions Edinburgh on Saturday in arguably the toughest challenge the York team has faced yet in this their maiden BUCS Northern Premier League season (Thumbnail credit The women's fencers have competed manfully, but still sit second bottom in the Northern Premier League. Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

Matt Hallam

Two weeks ago Derwent Captain Matt Hallam was involved in an accidental incident in a match against Wentworth that left him with a broken nose. Does he think that college football is worryingly violent? As he runs us through the experience the answer becomes abundantly clear

College Football: The case for the defence

Even in the sheltered world of Premier League football, where players are employees rather than supporters, there exists an intense passion and rivalry. It should come as no surprise then that the college football league has a tribal quality to it as teams fight for bragging rights each Sunday (Thumbnail credit Derwent's Xander Brinkworth shoots for goal in Sunday's 7-0 win. Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

Half-term report: The Nouse Sport form XI

By James Bithell

The Nouse Sport team present their best starting XI players from so far this term

Goodricke top the league as perfect record continues

By James Bithell

Goodricke came from a goal down to beat Vanbrugh 2-1 in college football's top of the table clash. Despite enduring a frustrating first half, Goodricke rallied well to play some impressive attacking football and were unlucky to not have won by more (Thumbnail credit Sharpe-shooters: Goodricke celebrate victory number five. Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

Show me the money

Sports Editor Henry Cowen talks to football agent David Baldwin, who represents 25 internationals around the world, about his job and whether he's ruining football. The outcome is far less cynical than one might like to believe (Thumbnail credit Aaron Ramsey and Emilio Izaguirre are just two of Baldwin's many clients, but is he doing them a service or is he using them? Photo: Ronnie MacDonald)

Octopush extends its reach

Sport can be the one safety net when you first come to university. It can be the guiding hand, the familiar face, the one piece of normality for freshers ousted from the sanctuary that is school or college and thrown into a world of unknowns (Thumbnail credit Photo: Peter Iveson)

The Mixer

The Mixer is a big fan of charity. We think that uber-telethons where the world and their D-List wife turn up to promote their latest album, tour or work-out DVDs are works of unalloyed altruism not seen since they days of St Francis of Assisi

Nouse Sports Podcast

By James Bithell

The weather might be getting harsher but Nouse's sports reporters are a hardy bunch so here is the Nouse Sport Podcast, complete with analysis of Wednesday's BUCS fixtures as well as discussion on the wider world of sport. (Thumbnail credit The Nouse Sport Podcast's biggest fan, Richard Larkin, does battle for the men's hockey firsts against Durham fourths. Image: Peter Iveson)

Men's fencers battle to convincing win

The men's fencers earned a comfortable victory over the University of Sheffield on Wednesday, overcoming them 135-92 (Thumbnail credit The men's fencers, seen here in action at the beginning of the month. Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

Women's badminton team's winning streak continues

The women's badminton side carried on their successful start to the season with a 6-2 victory over the University of Huddersfield on Wednesday. (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Inconsistent offence kills Centurions' comeback

York's American Football side the York Centurions came out on the wrong side of a 12-2 scoreline against Huddersfield Hawks at the weekend, as they begin their second season in the British Universities American Football League (Thumbnail credit Image: Gareth Dowse)

Men's Volleyball crush UCLAN

York men's Volleyballers put a recent bad run to and end with a comfortable 3-0 win over the University of Central Lancashire. (Thumbnail credit Image: Charlie Woods)

York's women stick eight past Leeds

York's women hockey players continued their unbeaten start to the season with a resounding 8-0 win over Leeds fourths this afternoon. (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

Rugby seconds miss out by one point

The men's seconds fought bravely against Durham University thirds today but fell short by one point. (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

Sheffield too strong for York

The men's squash team find themselves on a run of four games without a win after losing out to Sheffield University 4-1 this afternoon. (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)
